data.title: 2025 Alfa Romeo Milano, er, Junior marks Italian brand's first full EV
data.meta_description: The compact SUV comes in hybrid trims, too, and will appear in Europe before debuting in other markets—but likeky not Canada
data.text:
Advertisement 1

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Milano will be Alfa’s first EV, but also comes in hybrid powertrains

Subcompact SUV is roughly Kia-Soul-sized, but obviously pointed way up-market

It launches in Europe, but hasn’t been ruled out for the Canadian market

Some five days after Milano’s launch, Alfa Romeo announced it’d changed the name to ‘Junior’

Two months after its reveal, Alfa adjusted the output figures of the Veloce trim up by 39 hp

Advertisement 2

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

2025 Alfa Romeo Milano, er, Junior marks Italian brand's first full EV Back to video

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Alfa Romeo early April pulled the covers off of its all-new Milano compact SUV, a stylish new entrant in Europe’s largest automotive segment that simultaneously revives a name from the company’s history whilst infusing roads on the continent with a dose of Italian flair.

UPDATE April 15, 2024: Well, that didn’t last long. The day after the launch of the Milano, Italy’s minister of industry called out the automaker for naming the sport-utility after an Italian city – the hometown of the brand – while assembling it in Poland, which marked the first time an Alfa will be built entirely outside of Italy. Not only did Adolfo Urso find this gauche, he also denounced it as illegal.

“A car called Milano cannot be produced in Poland,” Reuters quotes the minister. “This is forbidden by Italian law,” apparently referring to 2003 legislation that “targets ‘Italian-sounding’ products that falsely claim to be Italian.”

Learn more about the cars

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

As a result, Alfa Romeo on April 15 said it’d changed the model’s name to Junior, also a nod to Alfa’s heritage. Both names were selected by a popular vote of the public, the company says. Our original article continues unchanged below. —Ed.

UPDATE June 20, 2024: After further “dynamic testing,” Alfa Romeo revealed it’d underestimated the output of the top-trim Veloce variant of the Junior. The thing actually churns out 278 horsepower, not 240-ish as it’d first thought. Damn. —Ed.

Designed in Turin, the Milano is a four-door compact hatchback set to be offered with hybrid and all-electric powertrain options, slotting in under the Stelvio and Tonale in Alfa’s family tree. It is in fact the first battery-driven Alfa Romeo, with EV variants flying the “Elettrica” flag and showing up with either 156 horsepower or, in “Veloce” spec, 240 ponies.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The base trim will have a driving range of roughly 255 miles (410 km) on a fully charged 54-kWh battery. Some components are shared with the Fiat 600 and Jeep Avenger – two other models we don’t get here – which makes sense, since those brands are also under the Stellantis umbrella.

Recommended from Editorial

2024 Alfa Romeo Tonale Veloce eAWD is good, but not great

Alfa Romeo's new Tonale will start at $44,995 in Canada

Overall length is stated to be 4,170 mm (164.1 inches) which makes it about the same size as a Mini Countryman or a Volvo EX30.

Styling carries a wealth of Alfa DNA, with a bold nose bookended by LED matrix headlamps. Its rear door handles are tucked into the pillar just head of the shadow of a new take on the Alfa Romeo logo. The brand promises entertaining driving dynamics, thanks to utilizing the same team that fettled the Giulia GTA at the brand’s Balocco testing centre in Vercelli province.

Inside, one will find expressive Italian nods and the typically large digital screens expected these days. Air conditioning vents in the shape of a quadrifoglio (four-leaf clover) are a nice touch.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Will it come to North America? Mexico was specifically mentioned as an example of a possible future market for the Milano, so that’s a start — though there are plenty of models which never make it north of the Rio Grande for a multitude of reasons. [UPDATE: Apparently a representative for Alfa Romeo’s North American operations confirmed there are no plans to bring the Milano to the U.S., which suggests there’s little chance Canada will see it either. —Ed.)

As for pricing, one particularly verbose spox for the brand bragged that Alfa is both inclusive and exclusive now that it ranges from “two million to thirty k.” Logically speculating the man was talking about price, this suggests the Milano could start around 30,000 euros (CDN$44,000) when it goes on sale in that market.

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Before wrapping this post, it is worth mentioning that top Stellantis boss Carlos Tavares spent a not-insignificant amount of time pontificating on the future of the company and its desire to remain in Italy. In fact, he hammered home the notion that it feels at home in Italy, and somewhat derided the purchase of Volvo and MG brands by Chinese interests, going on to say “this will not happen with Alfa Romeo.” Alright, then.

The new Milano is expected to be available to order in Europe sometime this summer.

Matthew Guy

Matthew Guy is a lifelong gearhead who writes automotive content for Canadian and American outlets. He is alternately described as a freelance author, podcast host, road test magnate, and legend in his own mind. As a member of AJAC, he enjoys sharing his excitement about cars and is very pleased to contribute at Driving.

EXPERIENCE

Matthew’s goal is to put readers in the driver’s seat for a unique and entertaining look at the automotive industry – whether penning vehicle reviews with a creative bent, travelling to manufacturer events for first drives of new models, or speaking with industry stakeholders to gain extra insight for an article During the past decade, he has enjoyed creating unique and creative long-distance adventure drives, sating his (and the reader’s) appetite for driving accomplishments like traversing the spartan wilds of Labrador. Timed challenges in speedy machines also spin his crank. For a spell, he was also behind the microphone for this site’s Truck Guy podcast, interviewing guests ranging from knowledgeable local technicians to world-famous television stars. Find out what it’s like to jump behind the wheel of a pickup truck and successfully tackle gnarly off-road courses. Ride along whilst tackling twisty roads along the Pacific Coast in a droptop convertible. Bundle up as he explores the frigid expanses of Canada from his home on the East Coast to venturing north of the Arctic Circle.

EDUCATION

Memorial University of Newfoundland, School of Business B.Comm (Hons.)

AWARDS

2021 Castrol-Wakefield Automotive Writing Award, runner-up

Runner Up - 2023 AJAC Adventure and Travel Journalism Award presented by Genesis Canada

Winner - 2023 AJAC Road Safety Journalism Award presented by Volvo Canada
